author: Special Correspondent
text:
Apart from alcohol, a problem that is worrying rehabilitation centres is prescription drug abuse among the middle-aged and cannabis usage among children, said V. Thirumagal, programme coordinator, T.T. Ranganathan Clinical Research Foundation (TTRCRF).

She was speaking to The Hindu at the closing ceremony of a one-month course on drug de-addiction counselling held in the city on Friday and sponsored by the National Institute of Social Defence, Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment, Government of India.

“It is a combination of alcohol and prescription drug abuse among many middle-aged men. Among women, it is mainly pain killers, which they start taking after some major injury. However, the most worrying trend is the use of ‘ganja’ by teenagers. It makes them angry,” she said.

Prem Anand Sinha, zonal director, Narcotics Control Bureau, was the chief guest. He spoke on substance abuse and also gave away certificates.

Over 25 persons from NGOs across the city took part. They were trained in topics such as addiction as a brain disease, problems faced by family members, drugs and abuse, basic counselling skills, treatment planning, sessions for patients and family, community-based treatment and relapse prevention.
title: Issue of prescription drug abuse highlighted
